div1.p: Frost offers comments on the inadequacy of the International Health Board Bulletin's published memorial to Henry Rose Carter, and encloses a letter from Frederick F. Russell in which Frost is asked to make additions and corrections to the printed memorial.

body.div1:
Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Laura Armistead Carter, September 9, 1926
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
615 NORTH WOLFE STREET
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY
BALTIMORE, MD.
Sept. 9th, '26.
My dear Miss Laura:
The enclosed letter
from Col. Russell came to my office
a week or more ago, but - as I've been
away most of the time since then I've
had no chance, until now, to follow it up.
Of course I shall be very happy to do
anything that. I may to help make the I. H. B.
memorial to your father more fitting. The
printed memorial (in the I. H. B. Bulletin of Oct, 1925)
seems to me, as it surely must seem
to you, to be utterly lacking in any real
appreciation of your father's greatness ex-
cept in the tributes quoted from Hanson,
Connor & Thayer; and I want to do all of
can to makehelp make the contemplated “minute”
more appropriate; and to this and I want,
2
first of all any suggestions or material that
you may think appropriate. As I under-
stand it the minute will be written by
the Committee-presumably by Dr. Welch, &
what is necessary is merely to furnish them
the material for it., I think, however, that
this should be not merely bare facts, but-
should include “in large letters” an appre-
ciation of the enormous importance of
your father's work & of his greatness of
intellect & soul.
A few days ago, while in Washington, I
took occasion to get out of the Bureau files
& to read your father's “autobiography”, which
not only gave a pretty complete record of
his Service duties but also gave me some
view of his own ideas as to the relative
importance of his various work. However,
this record was evidently written about 1912
or earlier, & gives an account of his work
in recent years in the study & control of
malaria in recent years--which, a you
will note, is very lightly touched in the
I. H. B. memorial.
3
Without having formed any definite plan,
what I have in mind at present is;
I To emphasize much more the account of
his accomplishments in solving the epidemiology &
control, first, of yellow fever and then of malaria.
To do this, I think the account given should:
(1) Explain more fully & clearly the first reaction,
importance of the efforts which he began at
Ship Island in '88. Not only did it lead to the
formulation of thoroughly rational & at the
same time far less onerous quarantine practice
(which have made it possible ever since to
maintain free communication between endem-
ic areas & our own infectible territory); it
also very clearly led him into his real study
of yellow-fever, especially its incubation-per-
iod, which was the key to quarantine practice;
(2) To give a more graphic account of his dis-
covery of the extrinsic incubation period: calling
attention to the remarkable observation & clear
reasoning which it represented & to its fun-
damental significance, which has been generally
overlooked only because the experimental
proof followed so close upon it's heels.
(3) To at least record the fact of his close
personal relations in Havana with Gorgas
& also (I believe) with Reed. To those who
4
know Dr. Carter's reasoning powers this generosity
in counsel the inference is obvious.
(4) To state clearly that in Panama he was not
only Director of Hospitals, but also intimately
associated both personaly & officially with the
sanitary control, bring officialy second in com-
mand of the work & personally Gorgas' chief adviser
& friend.
(5) To give a fuller & better account of his work
after leaving Panama, i.e his work on malaria
in this country & his work on yellow fever else-
where. For this I lack the necessary data, which
I hope you can supply.
(6) To give a more informative & appreciative ac-
count of his last work, in the history of yellow
fever, for which also I lack the facts.
II. To make it clear that his achievement is
not to be measured by any objective account
of his own work, because he was altogether
unmindful of personal credit [unclear] himself
larger in working for or through others.
III. To picture a little more (- no one could
do it adequately) his personal qualities of
greatness - his insatiable scientific curiosity,
his store of knowledge & precise analysis, his abso-
lutely impartial & impersonal honesty of intellect,
his generosity, his absolute devotion to duty,
his modesty, his enthusiasm, his courage &
all the qualities which made him the rare
& great man that he was.
All this however, is merely by way of showing
you what is at present in my mind, and
that for no purpose but to get your
own ideas, for certainly you know him
better than anybody else & what would best
serve the purpose would be to give them a
much as possible of what you know of your
father & his work, & that is, in fact, what
I want to do.
I hope, from your letter to Susan, that we
will be seeing you soon, but in the mean
time I should like very much to hear from
you about this. Your ideas & any facts
which you think pertinent.
I am ashamed of myself for not having
written you long ago the letter that I prom-
ised but - somehow I just haven't been able
to do it. I think, before I can do it that I
need to talk to you again to get any mind
stirred out of its habitual torpor. Certainly I
have never forgotten my promise, but have
only felt that until something stirred me to
it I could not possibly express what
I want to say.
Susan sends love to you and I most
cordial regards, to which little Susan would
surely add some message if she were here;
& we all look forward with most pleas-
ant anticipations to your long-deferred visit.
I hope your summer's rest -- if it has
been rest -- has done you much good
& that you'll come back prepared to
enjoy work which I am sure is the
normal condition for your father's daughter.
Sincerely yours, Wade H. Frost.
P.S. Have you a full bibliography of
your father's writings? If so I should like
to have it to copy tho' I don't think it is
needed for the I.H.B.
W.H.F.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Wade Hampton Frost, August 30, 1926
div1.opener:
COPY
INTERNATIONAL HEALTH BOARD
of
THE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION
61 Broadway, New York.
August 30, 1926.
Dear Dr. Frost:
div1.p:
A committee of our directors, consisting of Dr. Welch,
Dr. Flexner and Dr. Edsall, was appointed to draft a minute with
reference to Dr. Henry Rose Carter to be presented at the next
meeting of the Board. We here in the office are preparing a
memorandum for the use of this committee on Dr. Carter's life.
We have already prepared one for publication in the International
Health Board Bulletin, and I am sending you a copy of this. You
would help us greatly if you would look this over and make such
additions and corrections as you think desirable.

I am making this request of you because it has always
been my belief that you knew more about Dr. Carter than anyone
else of my acquaintance. We desire to have an accurate and
fitting minute for the records of our Board, and I am sure that
the Directors, as well as the officers, will appreciate any help
you can give us.

I trust that you have had a pleasant vacation and that
your work this fall will go well.

I might add that the meeting of the Board comes the
first week in November and that we would like to have all the
manuscript ready for the docket by the first of October. If
you could send us the data before that date, it would be greatly
appreciated.
